description: Driving and distorted riffs, aggressive drumming, vigorous vocals, and an all-around show of brute force in its early days, since branching into dozens of subgenres.

subgenres.name: Alternative Metal
subgenres.description: Mid-tempo style emphasizing melodicism and rhythmic heaviness; branches outside of the stylistic conventions of Metal.

subgenres.name: Funk Metal
subgenres.description: Melds Funk Rock grooves with slap basslines and metallic guitarwork.

subgenres.name: Neue Deutsche Härte
subgenres.description: Alternative Metal and Industrial Metal that incorporates various aspects of electronic music, specifically Electronic Dance Music.

subgenres.name: Nu Metal
subgenres.description: Emphasizes bouncy, drop-tuned riffs, alternating vocal styles, and genre-bending, often incorporating Hip Hop and Funk Metal elements.

subgenres.name: Rap Metal
subgenres.description: Features rapped vocals, typically formed around heavy, mid-tempo, and groove-oriented playing in addition to elements of Hip Hop beats such as record scratching.

subgenres.name: Avant-Garde Metal
subgenres.description: Often breaking the bounds of the genre through experimental structures and instrumentation, or by incorporating outside influences.

subgenres.name: Black Metal
subgenres.description: Typified by highly distorted, trebly, tremolo-picked guitars, blast beats, double kick drumming, shrieked vocals, and raw, underproduced sound that often favors atmosphere over technical skills and melody.

subgenres.name: Atmospheric Black Metal
subgenres.description: Focuses on the atmospheric element using slowly developing riffs, repetitive melodies, usually slow to medium tempos, and commonly synthesized ambient textures.

subgenres.name: Blackgaze
subgenres.description: Melds tremolo-picked riffing, high-gain guitars, and harsh, often wailing, vocals with mellow, dreamy textures and melodic song structures.

subgenres.name: Black 'n' Roll
subgenres.description: Incorporates elements of Hard Rock, Glam Rock, and Heavy Metal.

subgenres.name: Black Noise
subgenres.description: Incorporates unconventional sounds with overpowering or constant Noise and Black Metal elements, often being heavily texture-oriented, abrasive, dissonant, atonal, or repetitive.

subgenres.name: Depressive Black Metal
subgenres.description: Characterized by lethargic atmospheres; usually repetitive song structures and slow-mid tempos; high-pitched wailing and gruff vocals; and usage of non-distorted instruments like keyboards and acoustic guitars.

subgenres.name: Melodic Black Metal
subgenres.description: Cleaner production, more diverse arrangements, and a stronger emphasis on melody than is typical for Black Metal.

subgenres.name: Pagan Black Metal
subgenres.description: Incorporates acoustic guitar and traditional instrument passages, cleanly sung vocals, folk songs' melodies, and paganistic themes.

subgenres.name: Symphonic Black Metal
subgenres.description: Symphonic soundscapes, typically but not always synthesized.

subgenres.name: War Metal
subgenres.description: Aggressive, chaotic, and heavily Death Metal-influenced.

subgenres.name: Death Metal
subgenres.description: Features distorted, commonly down-tuned guitars; palm-muted and tremolo-picked riffs; aggressive, double-kicked percussion that utilizes various blast beats techniques; abrupt changes in tempo and time signatures; and guttural vocal styles.

subgenres.name: Brutal Death Metal
subgenres.description: Emphasizes abrasiveness, chunky rhythmic atonal riffs, and low guttural vocals.

subgenres.name: Slam Death Metal
subgenres.description: Focuses on slow or midtempo (as well as breakdown-style) sections built on chromatic, palm-muted riffs - so-called 'slams'.

subgenres.name: Death 'n' Roll
subgenres.description: Incorporates a groove-oriented, Hard Rock-influenced approach while retaining heavily distorted rhythm guitars and gruff or occasionally growled vocals.

subgenres.name: Deathgrind
subgenres.description: Combines the intensity and high-pitched screams of Grindcore with the technicality and low guttural vocals of Death Metal.

subgenres.name: Melodic Death Metal
subgenres.description: Utilizes the guitar harmonies and melodic sound of Heavy Metal, while keeping the main characteristics of Death Metal.

subgenres.name: Technical Death Metal
subgenres.description: Focuses on challenging, demanding songwriting and instrumental skill.

subgenres.name: Dissonant Death Metal
subgenres.description: Emphasizes discordant, dense songwriting and utilizes pinch harmonics, scratchy guitar leads, and atonality.

subgenres.name: Doom Metal
subgenres.description: Plodding tempos, repeated chords, and thick, distorted, down-tuned guitars in a style focused on foreboding, atmosphere, and tension.

subgenres.name: Death Doom Metal
subgenres.description: Fuses down-tuned guitars, growled vocals, and aggressive, often double-kick drumming with a mournful, somber atmosphere and plodding tempos.

subgenres.name: Funeral Doom Metal
subgenres.description: Features exceptionally slow, funeral dirge-like tempos, heavily distorted, sluggish guitars, mournful atmosphere, and distant, hushed growls and grunts.

subgenres.name: Traditional Doom Metal
subgenres.description: Monotonous and heavy playing style; repetitive, rough, and sometimes atonal guitar riffs; a 'rocking to sleep' bass; and influences from both Blues Rock and Psychedelic Rock.

subgenres.name: Epic Doom Metal
subgenres.description: Emphasizes Heavy Metal influence and theatrical vocals.

subgenres.name: Drone Metal
subgenres.description: Composed with heavy repetitive drones, minimalist structure, and slow tempos.

subgenres.name: Folk Metal
subgenres.description: Features influences from various types of Traditional Folk Music expressed through melodies and/or traditional instrumentation, notably having a large scene in Europe.

subgenres.name: Celtic Metal
subgenres.description: Features Celtic Folk Music elements.

subgenres.name: Mittelalter-Metal
subgenres.description: Emerged as a metallic style in the mid-to-late 1990s from the German Neo-Medieval movement.

subgenres.name: Gothic Metal
subgenres.description: Features heavy, low-mid tempo riffs, somber, gloomy atmosphere accentuated by ethereal keyboards and synthesizer layers, and vocal styles ranging from raspy growls to female operatic singing.

subgenres.name: Grindcore
subgenres.description: Features shortened song structures and a diverse palette of intense techniques such as blast and skank beats, tremolo and down-picking, and various harsh vocal styles.

subgenres.name: Cybergrind
subgenres.description: Standard conventions of Grindcore taken to an even more discordant and rapid-fire extreme, with added Electronic dimensions of computer-generated noises and drum machines.

subgenres.name: Deathgrind
subgenres.description: Combines the intensity and high-pitched screams of Grindcore with the technicality and low guttural vocals of Death Metal.

subgenres.name: Goregrind
subgenres.description: Death Metal-influenced riffs with rhythms ranging from very fast to slower mid-tempos correlated with pitch-shifted vocals, sloppy playing and production, and gore-themed aesthetics.

subgenres.name: Gorenoise
subgenres.description: Combines and subverts Goregrind and Grindcore with brash Noise and even faster drum tempos.

subgenres.name: Pornogrind
subgenres.description: Groovy, mid-tempo style known for its exaggerated bouncy rhythm and common pornographic themes.

subgenres.name: Mincecore
subgenres.description: Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on Punk structures while including political and socially aware themes.

subgenres.name: Noisegrind
subgenres.description: Noise-driven, defined by its rawness, feedback usage, and very brief song structures.

subgenres.name: Groove Metal
subgenres.description: Midtempo riffs influenced by Thrash Metal but with a greater focus on rhythmic syncopation and heaviness over speed.

subgenres.name: Heavy Metal
subgenres.description: Heavier outgrowth of Hard Rock featuring greater distortion and intensity along with lesser Blues influences.

subgenres.name: NWOBHM
subgenres.description: Acronym for new wave of British Heavy Metal, which occurred in the late 1970s, taking some influence from Punk Rock.

subgenres.name: Speed Metal
subgenres.description: Originating from the NWOBHM and influenced by the work of early heavy metal bands, being faster and somewhat more aggressive than heavy metal.

subgenres.name: US Power Metal
subgenres.description: American style influenced by NWOBHM that features heavily distorted guitars paired with more aggressive riffs, mid-tempo Heavy Metal rhythms, and over-the-top theatrical vocals with fantasy or conceptual themes.

subgenres.name: Industrial Metal
subgenres.description: Incorporates the abrasive and heavy sound from Industrial into a Metal context by using elements from Post-Industrial like synthesizers and drum machines.

subgenres.name: Cyber Metal
subgenres.description: Originated around 1999, influenced by EBM and Aggrotech with more melodic and less repetitive riffs as well as harsh vocals.

subgenres.name: Neue Deutsche Härte
subgenres.description: Alternative Metal and Industrial Metal that incorporates various aspects of electronic music, specifically Electronic Dance Music.

subgenres.name: Kawaii Metal
subgenres.description: Combines a heavy and metallic style with an upbeat, J-Pop-indebted tone and vocal style; associated with a 'kawaii' aesthetic.

subgenres.name: Metalcore
subgenres.description: Drop-tuned guitar riffs, constant double kick drumming with varying tempos and techniques, breakdown sections, and screaming or shouting vocals.

subgenres.name: Deathcore
subgenres.description: Fusion genre integrating elements from Death Metal, using harsh guttural vocals, blast beats, and palm-muted or tremolo-picked riffs in conjunction with breakdowns.

subgenres.name: Downtempo Deathcore
subgenres.description: Slow and minimal songs emphasizing breakdowns, atmosphere, and dissonance with downtuned guitars.

subgenres.name: Mathcore
subgenres.description: Rhythmically complex, features unconventional time signatures, syncopated and dissonant riffs and erratic metric shifts.

subgenres.name: Melodic Metalcore
subgenres.description: Originated in the late 1990s when some metalcore bands infused elements of Melodic Death Metal into their sound to create a more metallic and melodic style.

subgenres.name: Neoclassical Metal
subgenres.description: Greatly influenced by Western Classical Music in its style of playing and composing.

subgenres.name: Post-Metal
subgenres.description: Heavily utilizes timbre and texture to have enormous song build-ups and huge atmosphere.

subgenres.name: Atmospheric Sludge Metal
subgenres.description: Combines slow, churning guitar riffs and thunderous percussion with dark, extensive otherworldly sonic landscapes.

subgenres.name: Doomgaze
subgenres.description: Gloomy and somber atmosphere, amplified by the slow tempo and gloominess of Doom Metal, combined with the effects, washes of sound, and vocals found within Shoegaze.

subgenres.name: Power Metal
subgenres.description: Developed from Heavy Metal and Speed Metal; characterized by its emphasis on speed, vocal melody and harmonized lead guitars.

subgenres.name: Progressive Metal
subgenres.description: Fuses amplified, guitar-driven sound with technical proficiency, virtuosity, complex compositions, innovative arrangements, eclecticism, and additional instrumentation.

subgenres.name: Djent
subgenres.description: Syncopated rhythmic structures, angular melodies, and dissonant chords.

subgenres.name: Sludge Metal
subgenres.description: Combines the slow, dark instrumentals and atmosphere of Doom Metal with the aggressive, harsh screams and shouts credited to Hardcore Punk.

subgenres.name: Atmospheric Sludge Metal
subgenres.description: Combines slow, churning guitar riffs and thunderous percussion with dark, extensive otherworldly sonic landscapes.

subgenres.name: Southern Metal
subgenres.description: Blues-influenced style that primarily incorporates Sludge Metal and Stoner Metal with metallic Southern Rock riffs.

subgenres.name: Stenchcore
subgenres.description: Heavier, more metallic form of Crust Punk drawing influence from Thrash Metal as well as Death Metal and Heavy Metal.

subgenres.name: Stoner Metal
subgenres.description: Combines elements of Doom Metal with elements of Psychedelic Rock and Blues Rock to create a melodic yet heavy sound.

subgenres.name: Symphonic Metal
subgenres.description: Elements of symphonic and orchestral music.

subgenres.name: Thrash Metal
subgenres.description: Features fast tempos; rhythmically focused, frequently palm-muted riffs; shredding solos; aggressive, often double-kicked drumming; skank beats; and vocal styles ranging from shouts to melodic singing.

subgenres.name: Crossover Thrash
subgenres.description: Fusion of Thrash Metal and Hardcore Punk which started in the 1980s.

subgenres.name: Technical Thrash Metal
subgenres.description: Places great emphasis on complex songwriting and demanding instrumental parts.

subgenres.name: Trance Metal
subgenres.description: Tempo between 130 and 160 BPM, played with keyboards and metal instrumentation, sung with harsh and aggressive vocals including many clean melodic styles; regularly uses elements of Melodic Death Metal, Symphonic Metal, and Electronic Dance Music.

subgenres.name: Viking Metal
subgenres.description: Developed out of Black Metal and embodies an epic, Viking-like aesthetic.
